Anyway, as the title says, this song is about overwhelming love.
This song is about overwhelming love, absolute love.
It's a song about overwhelming love, absolute love.
My name is Mana, which means "love" in Japanese, and I use the kanji for "love" in my name.
I use the kanji character for love in my name and it means "love is fragrant" and I read it as "Managawa".
So when I received this song, I was very happy to hear the word "love" in it.
I thought about how to express this love in my own way.
I don't know who the other girl is, the guy or the girl, but I think it's about the person you love, no matter how much you resist it.
I don't know who the guy or girl is, but to the person she loves, no matter how hard she tries to resist, she can't do it, because she already loves him or her.
I don't know who the guy or girl is, but I think she's in love with the person she loves.
It's a song about the love that you can't help but love, no matter how much you resist.
So I made a lot of faces to the camera to convey that.
I tried to make a lot of expressions saying "I love you" to the camera.
I hope that people watching the song can understand that.
We had a lot of discussions together, not only about the lyrics but also about the music.
We discussed not only the lyrics, but also the music together, and I was able to make requests such as, "I personally prefer a more sparkling sound here.
I'd like to hear a little more sparkle here and there.
The chorus was supposed to have an exotic sound, but I think it would have been better to have a sparkling sound rather than that.
I thought it was easy for me to get emotionally involved in the song.
I thought it would be easier for me to get emotionally involved in the song.
The arrangement was done just the way I wanted it.
Anyway, I love this song, so I hope you enjoy it as much as I do.
I hope you enjoy the world of this song as much as I do.

It's time for Ruri Hiromoto and Sumire Tashiro to say goodbye to Apkami!
We've seen a lot of footage this time.
I, Tashiro, was impressed by the making of Manaka Inaba's "Overwhelming Love" music video.
I was able to learn all about how Inaba-san really manages his facial expressions, and how he is so cute and carefree in his dancing.
I learned a lot from watching the making of the music video.
Next time I shoot a music video, I want to do my best with Inaba-san in mind.
Yes, and I, Hiromoto, really like instrumental recording.
When I come here to record, and when I watch it at home.
I am always very moved by the instrumental recordings.
I'm not the type of person who can handle an instrument well when I'm making it.
I'm not the type of person who can handle an instrument well
I'm not the type of person who can handle an instrument well, so I'm really impressed by the professional player's fingertips and sense of sound.
I think it's really cool to see a professional player's fingertips and sense of sound, and the way they listen to you.
I wonder if I can become like them.
I hope I can be influenced by them and train my own sense of sound.
At Atami, you can get a behind-the-scenes look at the production of various artists belonging to the Upfront Group.
We'll take you behind the scenes of the production of various artists belonging to the Upfront Group.
Please subscribe to our channel so we can show you what you don't normally see!
This time, our partners in Appukami are Ruri Hiromoto of Ocha-no-Oma and Sumire Tashiro of Ocha-no-Oma!
Good bye.

and the recording of Tsubaki Factory's latest album "Third Moment"!
